div.p: S. D. I sealed the previous letters when yours were delivered to me, and since there was nothing in them that required a response, I have only added this note. I congratulate you for having escaped safely from that insane and raging flood of waters. I am also glad that peace is confirmed by the legate. As for the bishop creating a new abbot in Disentis, he could easily have refrained from that innovation. Borromeo had an uncle, Giovanni Giacomo de' Medici, lord of Musso; he does not favor the Swiss, who expelled his uncle. If you learn anything about his plans, make sure to let me know promptly. I trust in nothing good.

He would like to nest in the four bailiwicks beyond the mountains; a monster is being nurtured. Beware, lest that Schwenckfeldian and Anabaptist is received back into favor, unless you wish to experience the greatest disturbances again.
Yours truly, who always wrote this on the same 1st of September 1570.
To Tobias Egli, minister of the church in Chur, his beloved brother. Chur.
